# What are functions?

.font120[
<blockquote>
A function is a type of object in R that can perform a specific task. 
]

.font120[
- Functions take arguments as input and output some manipulated form of the input data.

- A function is specified first with the object name, then parentheses with arguments inside.

]

--

```{r}
# a simple in-built function
log(4)
```

---
class: middle

# When to write functions?

.font120[

- Using the same code more than once

- Complicated operation

- Vectorization

]

---
class: middle

# Function arguments

.font120[
- `x`, `y`, `z`: vectors.
- `w`: a vector of weights.
- `df`: a data frame.
- `i`, `j`: numeric indices (typically rows and columns).
- `n`: length, or number of rows.
- `p`: number of columns.
]

```{r}
# Basic Set Up
my_awesome_function <- function(x,y) # Arguments broken up by commas #<<
{ # Brackets that house the code 
  # Some code to execute 
  z = x*y 
  return(z) # Return a data value
} # Close the Brackets 
```

# More complicated functions

.code110[
```{r}
Operation_Times <- function(x, y, op){
   first_op <- switch(op,
     plus = x + y,
     minus = x - y,
     times = x * y,
     divide = x / y,
     stop("Unknown op!")
   )
   
   return(first_op * 2)
}
```
]

--

.code110[
```{r}
Operation_Times(x=5, y=6, op = "plus") #<<
```
]

# <i class="fa fa-pencil-square-o" style="font-size:48px;color:purple">&nbsp;Your&nbsp;Turn&nbsp;`r (yt <- yt + 1)`</i>    

Please git clone the repository on [simple functions](https://github.com/stat220/12-simple-functions) to your local folder. Write functions to calculate the variance and skewness of $X = \{12, 45, 54, 34, 56, 30, 67, \text{NA}\}$.

.font140[
$$\operatorname{Var}(x)=\frac{1}{n-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-\bar{x}\right)^{2}$$

$$\operatorname{Skew}(x)=\frac{\frac{1}{n-2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}-\bar{x}\right)^{3}\right)}{\operatorname{Var}(x)^{3 / 2}}$$
]

.fancy[
where $x_i = (\sum_i^n x_i)/n$ is the sample mean.] HInt: Use `sum()`


# if - else

```{r}
if(TRUE){
  print("Positive")
}else{
  print("Negative")
}
```

--

```{r}
if(FALSE){
  print("Positive")
}else{
  print("Negative")
}
```

---

# ifelse()

- Same idea just vectorized

```{r}
ifelse(T,"Positive","Negative")
```

--

```{r}
ifelse(F,"Positive","Negative")

```

--

```{r}
x <- 1:10
ifelse( x<5, "Positive","Negative")
```


---

# if and ifelse

```{r}
x <- c(3, 4, 6)
y <- c("5", "c", "9")
```

--

```{r}
# Use `if` for single condition tests
cutoff_make0 <- function(x, cutoff = 0){
  if(is.numeric(x)){
    ifelse(x < cutoff, 0, x)
  } else warning("The input provided is not a numeric vector")
}
```

--

```{r, warning=TRUE}
cutoff_make0(x, cutoff = 4)
```

--

```{r, warning=TRUE}
cutoff_make0(y, cutoff = 4)
```

`r chunk_reveal("demo1", widths = c(40, 40), font_size_code="100%", title = "## Visualizing Word Counts in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland")`

```{r,demo1, eval=FALSE, echo=FALSE }
alice %>% 
  mutate(linenumber=row_number()) %>% 
  unnest_tokens(word, text) %>% 
  anti_join(stop_words) %>%
  count(word, sort=TRUE) %>% 
  top_n(10) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(word, n)) + theme_tufte() +
  geom_col(fill = "#773232") + 
  xlab(NULL) + 
  coord_flip() + 
  ggtitle("Top words in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 8)) 
  
```

# Let function do it!

.code120[
```{r}
# Function to take the book id of books from project Gutenberg 
# Return a data tibble with smart words and their counts, sorted

word_count <- function(book_id) { #<<
    my_favorite_book <- gutenberg_download(book_id) %>% 
    mutate(linenumber=row_number()) %>% 
    unnest_tokens(word, text) %>% 
    anti_join(stop_words) %>%
    count(word, sort=TRUE)
my_favorite_book
}
```
]
